clinical_study.brief_title: TRANslating Sleep Health Into QUaLity of Recovery (TRANQUiL) Study
clinical_study.official_title: TRANslating Sleep Health Into QUaLity of Recovery (TRANQUiL) Study: A Multi-center Prospective Cohort Study of Sleep Health and Activity Measures Predicting Meaningful and Patient-centric Outcomes Following Non-cardiac Surgeries.

brief_summary.textblock: This is a novel observational study to evaluate the association between poor sleep health and poor quality of recovery in the surgical setting.

detailed_description.textblock:
Surgery and pain may cause sleep disturbances that affect both physical and mental well-being. Sleep disturbance can cause increased risk of confusion after surgery, increased pain need medication and untoward events (heart and breathing problems), delayed recovery and increased length of hospital stay. Hospitalization interferes with sleep patterns which may cause poor quality sleep due to noise, light, pain, medication administration and nursing checks. The circadian rhythm which meant the "body clock" is 24-hour cycle that tells bodies when to sleep, rise-regulating many physiological processes. But sleep disruption can affect the body clock, which changes the hormonal level can cause poor wound healing. There are few sleep health measurements such as sleep quality, sleep timing, and sleep efficiency. This study is aimed to evaluate sleep problems before sleep disruption immediately after surgery and also evaluate the relation between poor sleep health and quality of recovery
Objectives of the study:
1. To examine the associations between specific preoperative sleep-health parameters predicting poor sleep health and patient-centered outcomes such as pain control, delirium, sleep-related quality of life and quality of recovery scores in the perioperative period.
2. To estimate the association between presence of intrinsic sleep disorders and patient centric outcomes such as pain control, delirium, sleep-related quality of life and quality of recovery scores in the postoperative period.
3. To validate a set of subjective and objective measures that measure various sleep health domains in the post-operative setting.

primary_outcome.measure: Quality of recovery-15 score at 48 hrs postoperatively
primary_outcome.description: QoR-15 Score is a validated patient-reported outcome questionnaire that measures the quality of recovery after surgery and anesthesia. Aggregate changes in QoR-15 scores (e.g., mean and SD) will be reported.

primary_outcome.measure: The diagnostic accuracy of each of the actigraphy derived measures
primary_outcome.description: The diagnostic accuracy of each of the actigraphy derived measures with reference to the standard test will be calculated using the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve, Sensitivity, Specificity, Positive predictive value (PPV), Negative predictive value (NPV), Positive Likelihood ratio, Negative Likelihood ratios, and Diagnostic Odds Ratio (DOR).

secondary_outcome.description: The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) is a standardized sleep questionnaire for multiple populations. It has seven component scores and a composite score to assess sleep health and daytime dysfunction in the past month.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 7 days prior surgery, 7 days, and 3 months postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: The Consensus Sleep Diary (CSD) is a standardized, prospective tool for tracking nightly subjective sleep.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 7 days prior surgery and 3 months postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: The short-form FOSQ-10 scale has good psychometric properties with increased usability. It is a disease-specific instrument designed to assess the sleep-related quality of life measures.

The HADS is a very brief, easy to use screening measure comprising of 14 items measuring cognitive and emotional aspects of anxiety and depression. It has good psychometric properties for medical patients.
Postoperative assessment of the fluid intake and output.

The VAS is a simple way for patients to rate the intensity of their pain. This pain scale shows a 10-centimeter line printed on a piece of paper, with anchors at either end and marked from 0-10. At one end is "no pain," and at the other end are "pain as bad as it could be" or "the worst imaginable pain."
Assessment of the severity of the postoperative complications

secondary_outcome.measure: Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) score
secondary_outcome.description: The WOMAC questionnaire assesses the three dimensions of pain, disability and joint stiffness in knee and hip osteoarthritis using a battery of 24 questions in 5-point Likert, 100mm Visual Analogue and 11-box Numerical Rating Scale formats. It is a valid, reliable and responsive measure of outcome, and has been used in diverse clinical and interventional environments.

The ESS is self-administered where the subjects are asked to rate on 0-3 scales how likely they would be to doze off or fall asleep in the eight situations. A summary score is generated where total score of >10 indicates excessive daytime sleepiness.

study_pop.textblock: 260 patients will be recruited from the preoperative clinics at major academic centers: Women's College Hospital (WCH) (coordinating center), Toronto Western Hospital (TWH), University Health Network (UHN); and St. Michaels Hospital (SMH), Toronto, Ontario.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Adult patients (>18 years).
2. ASA physical status I - IV.
3. Undergoing elective primary or revision lower limb joint replacement surgeries (such as total or partial hip or knee replacement).
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients undergoing emergency surgeries; cardiac, trauma, organ transplantation or organ retrieval, obstetric or intracranial neurosurgeries.
2. Pregnant or lactating patients.
3. Inability to wear study-related monitoring devices per instruction or provide informed consent limiting adherence to protocol.
